text:
Summer just wouldn’t be the same without
that crisp, nostalgic pool smell.

We chemically treat our public swimming holes
to rid them of any dangerous microorganisms,

but what most people don’t realize is that
those same chemicals are also undergoing reactions
with organic materials from, well, you.

Today we’re talking pool chem, and most
important of all, we’re going to answer

that age old question, is it okay to pee in
the pool?

Still waters tend to attract nasty microorganisms,
so to keep our pools free of these pests,

we most commonly disinfect the water with
compounds such as chlorine, sodium hypochlorite,
and calcium hypochlorite.

These compounds react with water to create
hypochlorous acid which acts as a big time

disinfectant and noted adversary of the still
water squad

But chlorination isn’t good at killing every
pathogen out there.

Cryptosporidium, for example, can cause pretty
intense intestinal disorders and pays no mind
to chlorine.

For this reason, ultraviolet light, ozone,
and bromine can also be used to tamper with
biomolecules that these microbes need to survive.

A lot of pools use a combination of treatments
to keep us safe, but these methods don’t
come without drawbacks.

Drawbacks like the ones that we, the swimmers,
bring into the mix.

The added disinfectants also react with organic
matter from our bodies such as dirt, sweat,

urine, and even lotions to create troublesome
compounds called disinfection byproducts,
or DBP’s for short.

When doing so, these reactions use up the
amount of disinfectant readily available to
ah, you know, disinfect the pool.

These compounds cause a range of not-so-good
health effects that have caught the attention
of many ‘a’ scientist.

Let’s get right into the nitty gritty here
folks, researchers estimate that pools contain

around 30-80mL of urine per person in the
pool.
So quit lying – we know what you did.

Urine contains a lot of urea, a compound that
reacts with chlorine to create trichloramine.

Urine for a real treat here folks -- it’s
this compound that’s behind the classic
pool smell.

It also happens to be what causes your eyes
to burn and turn all red.

But that’s not all, this compound, like
many other DBPs, has also been linked to respiratory

issues such as asthma, meaning that it can
be a serious problem for pool-goers, and especially

for professional athletes who spend a significant
portion of their days swimming in indoor pools.

Pee causes nearly half of the total DBPs produced
by recreational swimmers.

Then whatever’s hanging out on your skin
when you dive in brings other compounds to
the table.

It makes it quite difficult for researchers
to study given the range of things on our
skin at any given moment.

Even more bizarre is that new drugs on the
market also might interact with pool disinfectants

via your urine to create even more DBPs that
could have real consequences.
So what can you do about this issue?
The answer is in the bathroom.

Now that you know the chemistry, it’s your
civic duty to pee in the restroom, and also,

take a shower and rinse off every time you’re
about to get into the pool.

Also, make sure to share this video with your
friends to help get the word out so everyone

knows that there are actually real consequences
to peeing in the pool.

For a deeper dive on pool chem, check down
in the description for a link to C&EN’s

in-depth article on chemical reactions in
the pool.

Peeing in the ocean on the other hand is a
different story, so check out this video to
learn about that.

our alchemical history.
